definitions.definition: a thin flat piece of bread, meat, cheese, etc. that has been cut off a larger piece; a piece of cake that has been cut from a larger cake

examples.text: Cut the meat into thin slices.
a gin and tonic with a slice of lemon
The sausage is also sold pre-packed in slices.

definitions.definition: a part or share of something

examples.text: Our firm is well placed to grab a large slice of the market.
The rent for my room was a large slice out of my budget.
With this win, they can claim a slice of history.
Every organization in the land has tried to claim a slice of the cash from the National Lottery.
He needed a large slice of luck to win the game.
The agency takes a large slice of the profits.
They spend a fair slice of the budget on research and development.

definitions.definition: a kitchen utensil (= tool) that you use to lift and serve pieces of food
a shot that makes the ball go to one side rather than straight ahead, while turning round and round
a share or role in an interesting or exciting activity, especially one that makes money

examples.text: Foreign firms will all want a slice of the action if the new airport goes ahead.

definitions.definition: a film, play or book that gives a very realistic view of ordinary life

examples.text: This drama provides a slice of life in 1950s Connecticut.

definitions.definition: a share of the available money or benefits that you believe you have a right to

examples.text: The company is demanding a larger slice of the corporate pie.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘fragment, splinter’): shortening of Old French esclice ‘splinter’, from the verb esclicier, of Germanic origin; related to German schleissen ‘to slice’, also to slit.
